text: I did not.  I've essentially given up on it for now
Did there used to be an indication of each fields type (e.g. select, checkbox)? It would be helpful when looking for something specific.
Hi <!channel> Do you know if Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) in HubSpot only works for Blog pages or also in landing and website pages?
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/cos-general/how-to-use-accelerated-mobile-pages-amp-in-HubSpot>
Currently only for blog pages right now
Also, please refrain from using `@channel` or `@here` as this notifies all 424 people in the channel

only in blog pages. Also avoid using [at]channel and [at]here there are more than 400 people in this slack last i heard, using those pings everyone. There are enough active people in here that someone will get back to you in a relatively timely fashion, so there’s never really a need to use it except when there’s a dire emergency or HS staff want to announce something
Sorry Jon, don´t happen again :wink: and thank you for the answer!
Sorry <@U2H3TT8F2> and thank you for your answer <@U6GNQ7JBU>
I don’t think HS has any plans to roll out AMP for landing pages or website pages as AMP isn’t really meant for that.
I understand, a client wanted to know if AMP works on HubSpot since in wordpress seems to work for all web pages
AMP _currently_ only works for blog posts
Also in wordpress?
WordPress using plugins you can make anything use AMP. It’s not always the best solution though. as that means certain content wont be viewable to visitors arriving on an amp page

For Wordpress the post-type as the main type of content and it handles all content, by default, as such. This makes it simple to convert other post types to AMP pages, but it won’t work universally without theme or plugin level customization
Technically, you could use a blog post as any page on the site so you could have any page be AMP. You'd get analytics as if it were a blog post. But, it would work.

Amp is basically stripped back version of HTML with very limited javascript. There may even be some css limitations(not sure). 

If you want to fully amp a site, a lot of care and attention to detail should go into it to replace content with amp equivalents if possible.

For example say your homepage has a slider, an amp plugin may not interpret your slider is a slider and will just leave that out of the amp version of the page.

It’s largely intended for use for articles/blog posts. These pieces of content are generally simpler and don’t get too crazy.

For HS to add this to pages they’d essentially have to make an amp page builder.(more complex than with blog posts)
It makes all sense! It clarify me a lot! Thank you guys for your help. I will let my client know. I hope they finally choose HubSpot :+1:

Hi all, my name is Nicole, I'm a UX Researcher working with the Content Tools teams here at HubSpot. We're starting to explore local CMS development workflows and I was hoping you all could give me a couple minutes of your time and fill out this quick survey, <https://www.research.net/r/22LXYN2>. We'd love to know more about some of your processes to make sure we're creating tools that are useful to you. Thanks so much!

<!here> Happy Tuesday! We have one new addition to the new modules framework that I wanted to share. Users can now clone fields and filed groups when creating modules. You can check this out by hovering over a field or field group in the new module editor and clicking the _Actions_ dropdown.
